description: From outlaw +‎ -ry, after Anglo-Norman utlagarie, utlarie et al., and Late Latin utlagaria.

entries.meaning: (law, historical) A declaration that an individual cannot benefit from the protection of law in a jurisdiction. [from 14th c.]
examples: Notwithstanding any disposition made or to be made , by virtue or colour of any attainder , outlawry , fugacy , or other forfeiture

entries.meaning: The state of being an outlaw; lawlessness. [from 19th c.]
examples: Through this ‘passing-out ceremony’ the apprentice became both proven in reliability and bound, Faust-like, to the rebel cause by his act of outlawry.
